formats.name: Common Platform Enumeration
formats.description: CPEs are a defined identifier issued by software producers or third-parties based on entries in the central CPE dictionary, maintained by NIST. They're commonly used in vulnerability management systems like NIST's National Vulnerability Database (NVD).

formats.name: Package URL
formats.description: Package URLs represent software distributed through package hosts like NPM, RubyGems, and PyPI.

formats.name: OmniBOR Artifact ID
formats.description: OmniBOR Artifact IDs are inherent identifiers derived from the content of the artifact being identified.

formats.name: SoftWare Identification Tagging
formats.description: SWID Tags are defined identifiers assigned by the originator of the ID, either a software producer or a third-party attesting to it.

formats.name: Software Heritage Persistent Identifier
formats.description: SWHIDs are an inherent identifier used for identifying five kinds of objects: file contents, directories, revisions in a Version Control Systems' history, specific software releases, or snapshots of a point in a software project's history. They're intended for use in source code preservation and history tracking.

formats.name: Nix Store Path
formats.description: Nix Store Paths are an inherent identifier based on the build inputs used to produce the artifacts being identified. They're used to identify packages in the Nix ecosystem.

formats.name: Open Source Vulnerability Package Object
formats.description: OSV Package Objects are how the OSV database identifies packages for the purpose of vulnerability reporting and tracking. They're either a package name and ecosystem pair or a Package URL.
